Description.LocalizedString: If you lose a Survivor, listen for their footsteps. If injured, you'll also be able to hear their groans of pain.
Running Survivors leave red scratch marks in the environment that only Killers can see. Use them to track Survivor movements.
Killer add-ons can modify their power in many ways. They are consumed once the trial ends.
Hooking Survivors on The Entity's sacrificial hook is the Killer's primary goal, and awards a large number of Bloodpoints.
Though they share most basic abilities, every Killer has a unique power.
Generators being repaired are noisy. This can expose a Survivor's location or muffle their loud actions such as healing.
Loud noise events, such as when a Survivor misses a Skill Check, alert the Killer to the Survivor's location.
The Killer sees the aura (outline) of all unrepaired generators. Patrolling generators is a great way to find Survivors.
Killers can break dropped pallets. This action takes some time, but renders the pallet completely unusable.
A healthy Survivor hit by the Killer will enter the injured state. Another hit will put the Survivor into the dying state.
During a chase, the Killer must pay attention to the environment and the Survivor's movements to guess their next move.
Flashlights aimed at the Killer's eyes can briefly blind them and make them drop any Survivors they were carrying.
Survivors can eventually escape a Killer's grasp by wiggling free, so Killers should hook their victims quickly.
Survivors can drop pallets on the Killer to stun them temporarily.
Crows will take off and caw when disturbed. Killers can use the crows to pinpoint the location of moving Survivors.
The lunge attack grants a burst of speed, but the Killer is slowed while they recover.
When a Survivor is sacrificed, the hook is destroyed. This does not apply to basement hooks, which cannot be destroyed.
Each generator can suffer limited regression by the Killer, their perks, and addons before it can no longer regress.
When a Survivor disarms a Bear Trap, it triggers a loud noise notification at the Trap's location that the Killer can see.
Windows, pallets and narrow paths are great strategic locations to place Bear Traps.
The Trapper is notified when a Survivor is trapped. It's a race to grab them before they struggle free or are saved by others.
A careless Trapper can step into his own Bear Trap, causing him to drop any Survivor he was carrying.
The Trapper may reset a sprung Bear Trap without picking it up.
A Cloaked Wraith has a slight distortion when moving. He can also be detected by his snarling sound or with certain perks.
The Wraith's movement speed is reduced while Cloaking or Uncloaking.
The Wraith is vulnerable to Pallets when Cloaked. Stunning him with a Pallet will cause him to Uncloak.
The Wraith is faster when Cloaked and has no Terror Radius. He can interact with lockers/pallets/generators, but can't attack.
The Wraith rings a bell to Cloak and Uncloak. Survivors can hear him cloak from 40 meters, and his bell from 24 meters.
The Chainsaw charge grants the Hillbilly greatly increased speed, but severely limits maneuverability.
The Hillbilly can quickly shred through pallets with his Chainsaw.
Survivors hit by the Hillbilly's Chainsaw will be put into the dying state instantly.
Hitting walls or objects with the Chainsaw stuns the Hillbilly.
Using the Chainsaw fills the Overdrive meter. When full, the Chainsaw is enhanced with faster speed and shorter cooldowns.
Hitting a healthy Survivor grants them a short burst of speed.
After Blinking, The Nurse can attack or Blink again before becoming fatigued. Attacking after Blinking increases fatigue time.
The Nurse gets fatigued for a few seconds after a Blink. During this, The Nurse cannot attack/interact and has limited vision.
The Nurse can travel long distances quickly, through walls and objects, using her Blink ability.
The longer The Nurse charges her Blink, the further the distance she can travel.
The Nurse's Blink power comes at a cost. Her base movement speed is slower than most Killers.
At Evil Within tier I, The Shape is Undetectable, which allows him to lurk near victims without alerting them to his presence.
The Shape must keep Survivors in his line of sight while Stalking in order to build up his power.
When The Shape reaches Evil Within III, his vault speed & lunge range increase and attacks put Survivors into the dying state.
The Shape increases the power of his Evil Within by Stalking Survivors.
If a Stalked Survivor is highlighted red, no more power can be gained from Stalking them.
The Hag is smaller than other Killers, making her harder to spot from afar. She can use the terrain to hide her approach.
The Hag can Teleport to activated Phantasm Trap. Traps are white when she is in range to Teleport and red when she is not.
Survivors can avoid triggering Phantasm Traps by crouching past them. Try placing traps in places Survivors wouldn't expect!
The Hag can place up to 10 Phantasm Traps at once. Triggered traps disorient Survivors and allow The Hag to Teleport to them.
If multiple Phantasm Traps are activated, The Hag can prioritize which trap she will Teleport to by looking in its direction.
Survivors' Madness levels increase when struck by Shock Therapy or Static Blast attacks.
Successful Static Blast or Shock Therapy attacks on Survivors block their ability to perform any interaction for 2.5 seconds.
At Madness II, The Doctor can see Survivors' hallucinations. At Madness III, hallucination auras can be seen from a distance.
When reaching new levels of Madness, Survivors scream and reveal their location to all players.
Madness III: Survivors can't repair, heal, sabotage or cleanse. They must stop and "Snap Out of It" to return to Madness I.
Running leaves tracks only the Killer sees. Actions like fast vaults or fast locker entry cause visual cues for the Killer.
When injured, a Survivor can be healed by another Survivor, or they can heal themselves with a Med-kit.
When injured, a Survivor is easier to locate. An injured Survivor is more noisy and leaves behind a trail of blood.
Survivors are awarded Bloodpoints for completing objectives, evading the Killer, surviving trials and helping other Survivors.
A Survivor in the dying state cannot fully recover to the injured state without the help of a perk or another Survivor.
Skillful interactions such as repairing or healing will trigger Skill Checks. There is a sound before a Skill Check appears.
Generators can often be located by searching for the flashing lights above them.
Failing a Skill Check sets back an action's progress and notifies the Killer of the Survivor's location.
If a Survivor does not survive the trial, they lose any items they were carrying.
Survivors can attempt to evade Killers by hiding in lockers. Killers can search lockers, but spend precious time doing so.
A Survivor can try to unhook themselves (with 4% base chance of succeeding) at the cost of accelerating the sacrifice process.
The number beside the generator icon shows how many more generators the Survivors must repair before opening the exit gates.
The Terror Radius, or heartbeat, indicates the Killer's approach. The more intense it gets, the closer the Killer is!
Survivors vault more quickly through a window when running, but they are much louder and notify the Killer of their location.
Pulling down a pallet creates a loud noise that gives away your position to the Killer. It can also be used as a diversion.
Offerings are consumed once the match starts, unless they conflict with other offerings.
While in a trial, Survivors can swap their carried item for other items found in a chest or on the ground.
Killer Hex perks activate Dull Totems into Hex Totems. Cleansing a Hex Totem deactivates its associated Hex perk.
Successfully escaping the Killer during a chase awards Survivors with Bloodpoints.
Once five generators have been repaired, the Survivors' goal is to activate a gate switch to open an exit gate and escape.
Actions such as repairing generators or healing injured allies are performed faster when cooperating with other Survivors.
A Survivor hooked 3 times (or twice if they reached the 2nd phase of the process) will automatically be sacrificed.
If you are the last Survivor left, the Hatch may be an escape option! A Hatch icon in the lower left means it's open.
Carried Survivors can try to wiggle free from a Killer's grasp. If successful, the Killer is momentarily stunned.
Pay attention to the Killer's Red Stain. It tells you in which direction they are looking.
Survivors can scavenge items from chests which may increase their odds of survival.
The Entity will temporarily block a window for a Survivor who vaults through it repeatedly over a short period of time.
Dropping a pallet on a Killer momentarily stuns them.
Survivors in the dying state can still escape by crawling to the exit gates or the Hatch.
Pay attention to the other Survivors' status icons. They will let you know if Survivors are injured, dying or hooked.
Regressing generators need a minimum amount of repair progress to stop the regression.

Windows, pallets and choke points are often trapped. Survivors can escape on their own (16% chance) or be rescued by others.
When The Wraith is cloaked, look for his shimmer. He will move faster, have no Terror Radius, but cannot attack.
The Hillbilly sprints with the Chainsaw, breaks pallets, and drops Survivors in one hit, but is stunned when hitting objects.
The Nurse Blinks through walls. Anticipate where she will Blink, break line of sight, and escape while she is fatigued.
The Shapes power changes as he Stalks. Initially, hes slower and has a short lunge but has a much smaller Terror Radius.
The Hag can Teleport to a triggered trap within range. Survivors can avoid traps by crouching.
The Doctor inflicts Madness using Static Blast and Shock Therapy. There are 3 levels of Madness with various afflictions.
Injured Survivors leave trails of blood. Follow the blood trail to catch them before they can heal.
Survivors tend to run with a plan. When chasing, identify windows, pallets, and line of sight blockers to predict movements.
Attack a Survivor at close range when they're occupied to immediately pick them up. Lunge attacks do not trigger a pick-up.
When The Nurse is holding a fully charged Blink, she clenches her fist.
A distinctive audio cue can be heard once the Hatchet has been wound up to its maximum strength.
When out of Hatchets, search in any nearby lockers, indicated by a yellow aura. Every locker refills your Hatchets to maximum.
When charging the Hatchet Throw, the Huntress's move speed is slowed. A fully charged Hatchet Throw is slightly faster.
The Huntress can hit Survivors at a distance by throwing Hatchets. Listen for her humming to spot her before she spots you!
The Cannibal can spin, downing everyone around him. He is stunned when colliding with objects but his Chainsaw remains lethal.
You can quickly destroy pallets with your Chainsaw.
Your Chainsaw attack can down more than one Survivor at once. Use it on groups to a devastating effect.
Be careful not to run into obstacles while using the Chainsaw as you'll get stunned in a Tantrum.
While stuck in a Tantrum after hitting an obstacle with your Chainsaw, your Chainsaw is still deadly.
Hitting Survivors with your Chainsaw downs them instantly.
Use the highlighted Alarm Clock to wake up. This will pause the sleep timer for 30 seconds before you fall asleep again.
Your Dream Snares will slow Survivors as well as block Survivors from being able to fast vault windows.
Hitting an awake Survivor puts them to sleep. Sleeping Survivors are highlighted in blue and can trigger your Dream Abilities.
Each time a Survivor is woken, the Wake Up action takes longer. They can also awaken by failing Skill Checks. Look for this!
Sleeping Survivors hear a lullaby instead of the Terror Radius, making it harder for them to know where you're coming from.
Dream Projection causes a generator to spew blood. You can scare Survivors off generators, then cancel Dream Projection.
Use the Active Ability button to Crouch, mute your Terror Radius and sneak up on Survivors.
While Crouched, use your attack to launch a sprint attack. Hold down the attack interaction to perform a longer sprint.
Put traps on dying Survivors. They activate when a generator is fired up, giving 3 minutes for Survivors to find the key.
A Survivor with an activated Reverse Bear Trap on their head is killed if they attempt to escape through the exit gate.
You have a limited number of Reverse Bear Traps for the trial. You cannot get more during the trial.
The Pig can put Reverse Bear Traps on dying Survivors. Survivors must find the right key in a Jigsaw Box or be killed.
The Active Ability button reloads bottles. You carry a limited amount, so be strategic. Have enough bottles ready for a chase.
Aiming directly at Survivors is challenging. Instead, block them by aiming at objects like window frames, trees, and ceilings.
Hitting a Survivor directly with a bottle causes them to be even more visually impaired.
Survivors in Afterpiece tonic clouds are slowed and unable to do rushed actions. The Clown is immune to this effect.
Hold down the Power button to throw bottles further. This can be cancelled at any time by tapping the Attack button.
The Clown's bottles release gas clouds. Purple clouds are toxic to Survivors. Yellow clouds energize both Survivor and Killer.
When phasing, you can't see Survivors or blood trails, but can see scratch marks. Use them to track prey before reappearing.
You can't move when charging your power. Position yourself to cut off a Survivor's escape route once your power is charged.
If you stay still, feigning to charge Yamaoka's Haunting, you can trick Survivors into thinking that you are about to phase.
Yamaokas Haunting can be used in short bursts. The recharge time is based on the remainder of the power bar.
Use the husk to block the Survivor's path or interaction points, such as vaults or pallets.
The Spirit phases for a short time when using her power. While on the move, she cannot see Survivors or their blood trails.
Once you've hit a Survivor and inflicted Deep Wound, look around and make use of Killer Instinct to locate nearby Survivors.
Hitting a Survivor and inflicting the Deep Wound status effect will fully replenish your power gauge.
While Feral Frenzy is active, you can vault windows faster, and you can also vault pallets.
While Feral Frenzy is active, hitting a Survivor already affected by Deep Wound will completely deplete your power gauge.
If you successfully apply four instances of Deep Wound during Feral Frenzy, your next Feral Slash will instantly down a Survivor.
The Legion inflicts Deep Wound when their power is active. Stay out of their Terror Radius when afflictedthey can sense you.
Use Pools of Devotion tainted by sick Survivors to turn Vile Purge into a toxin that damages them. This lasts a short time.
Healthy Survivors who are infected will become injured when their infection indicator is completely filled.
While infected, a Survivor also increases their own level of infection by running or performing interactions like repairing.
Vile Purge infects objects like generators and pallets. Corrupt Purge injures Survivors but doesn't infect them or objects.
A completely infected Survivor transmits their sickness, causing objects and Survivors they interact with to become infected.
If your infection meter fills, you will be afflicted by the Broken status effect. Use Pools of Devotion to cure infection.
Try to stay hidden! Survivors can affect your ability to stay in stealth mode if they reveal you while Night Shroud is active.
With Night Shroud active you can Stalk and mark your victims! Marked Survivors become Exposed and are unable to reveal you.
Toggle Crouch with the Active Ability button. You will move slower but are harder to detect, especially with Night Shroud!
Move to the edge of a surface and hold the Power button with Night Shroud active to lean out of cover and Stalk your victims.
If you are revealed by a Survivor you will be briefly notified of their general direction by Killer Instinct.
Reveal Ghost Face by observing him while avoiding getting Marked. This deactivates his power but may let him know you're near!
If a Portal has been opened but not traveled through, it cannot be seen or destroyed by the Survivors.
Use your Shred action to close the distance on unsuspecting Survivors. The longer you charge it, the further it reaches.
When emerging from a Portal, you are Undetectable for a few seconds. Survivors won't hear you coming!
While traveling through Portals, you can still see generator and Survivor auras to help you maintain spatial awareness.
Fully charge your power to activate Of the Abyss and detect any Survivors within proximity to your Portals.
A sound is heard everywhere when The Demogorgon goes into a portal. When it emerges, it doesn't emit a Terror Radius.
Using Yamaoka's Wrath absorbs Blood Orbs when you're within a certain range of them.
Healthy Survivors release a larger amount of Blood Orbs when you damage them.
Injured Survivors slowly release Blood Orbs over time and also when performing certain actions like vaulting.
As soon as your power gauge is full, you can no longer see Blood Orbs or absorb them.
You have a limited range of movement while dashing, and it consumes your Blood Fury at a faster rate.
When Blood Fury is active, run or hide! The Oni can dash at high speeds and down Survivors in one hit.
Shoot, Reel, and strike Survivors through windows.
Shoot Survivors before they have time to drop a pallet and cut you off.
You can either Reel aspeared Survivor towards you or move towards them to close the distance.
The Speargun has a limited range but the projectile travels extremely fast. Shoot Survivors when they least expect it.
Using a basic attack while a Survivor is speared releases the Survivor from the chain, so make sure you hit them!
If you're hit by The Deathslinger's spear, pull away or make the chain collide with any obstacle, including other Survivors.
Survivors passing through Rites of Judgment reveal their position. The effect lingers momentarily when they leave the trail.
UsingRites of Judgment does not produce a trail on stairs, or in the Basement and Exit Area.
Use Rites of Judgment to detect Survivor positions through walls and attack using Punishment of the Damned.
Sending a Survivor to a Cage of Atonement counts as a normal hook for scoring and is not affected by perks that affect Hooks.
Survivors lose their Torment effect only after being saved from theCage of Atonement or by saving another Survivor from it.
Crouch through Torment Trails to avoid their effects. Perks affecting the hook will not apply while in a Cage of Atonement.
After Slamming into an obstacle, readjust your direction and launch a Lethal Rush. Wait too long and your Rush chain ends.
The more consecutive Rushes you perform, the longer it takes to replenish your Rush tokens and activate your power again.
Your turning is restricted while performing a Rush. Try to anticipate and predict a Survivor's next move before you Rush.
After Slamming into a wall or obstacle, you can still move around slightly to help adjust for your next Lethal Rush.
The Blight can't attack on his first Rush, having to Slam off an obstacle to do a Lethal Rush. His screech will alert you.
When approaching a Survivor as Victor, try to Pounce from a distance so they won't hear you coming.
Victor is vulnerable to being crushed by Survivors after downing or missing a Survivor with Pounce.
When controlling Charlotte, Victor can be left on the ground to help locate walking and running Survivors near him.
Pouncing and landing on a high-level surface with Victor will destroy him if he doesn't move off of it quickly.
Leaving Victor unattended for too long will cause him to reappear on Charlotte, as though a Survivor had crushed him.
Listen for the sound Victor makes before he pounces. If he misses or downs a Survivor, there's a moment you can crush him.
Antidote clouds are inactive until turning yellow. They give everyone a temporary speed boost and cure Intoxicated Survivors.
A Survivor's Laceration Meter decays when they're not hit by Blades. Keep pressuring!
While in the throw state, your movement speed is slightly reduced.
When running low on Blades, search lockers, as revealed by their yellow auras. Each locker refills your Blades to maximum.
Blade hits increase your Event Meter. When the Event Meter is full, Main Event becomes available for a moment.
Activating Main Event automatically starts a barrage of Blades at incredible speed.
The Trickster slows down when throwing Blades. Break line of sight long enough so your laceration meter decreases.
Killer Instinct reveals a Survivor's location when they use a Vaccine. Use this effect to track how many have been used.
Contaminate Survivors with Tentacle Strike. Subsequent Tentacle Strikes and zombie attacks damage Contaminated Survivors.
Contaminating Survivors with Tentacle Strike increases your Mutation Rate, as does destroying zombies with Tentacle Strike.
Pay attention to zombies' movements; their behavior can tell you if they've spotted or are tracking Survivors.
Destroyed zombies always respawn after a short time. They take a longer time to respawn when destroyed by Survivors.
When Contaminated, Tentacle Strikes and zombies damage you. Remove Contaminated with a Vaccine but be aware, they're limited.
The beginner tooltips can be disabled in the Settings under Tutorial in the General tab.
The possessed chain starts off slow and accelerates over time. You can adjust its trajectory before it reaches maximum speed.
Long-range pain is tempting but consider binding Survivors at short to mid-range so you can attack before they break free.
Picking up the Lament Configuration not only gives Survivors a jump scare, but also provides info on their whereabouts.
Killer Instinct reveals Survivors solving the Lament Configuration. You can teleport to them but doing so is a commitment!
When teleporting to a Survivor solving the Lament Configuration, they'll be bound by chains, temporarily unable to move.
The Cenobite can place gateways to scout areas. When a gateway spawns nearby, pay attention to avoid the chain.
You can use Dire Crows flying to detect Survivors running, hiding in lockers, or in the dying state.
Keep the Power Button held down when summoning a Dire Crow to quickly perform additional summons.
Each time you summon a Dire Crow, it resets the idle timer of the previously summoned Dire Crow.
The more Dire Crows taking flight, the longer the cooldown. If Dire Crows vanish without activating, the power quickly resets.
Hit a Survivor swarmed by Dire Crows with a second Dire Crow to damage them, regardless of how far the crow has flown.
The Artist can see the aura of Dire Crows swarming you, but not while you're performing the repel action.
TVs spawn by generators. Projecting to them helps find Survivors but shuts down the TV, briefly blocking Projection to it.
When demanifested, Survivors see only glimpses of your location at short range. Use this to get closer before Manifesting.
When Manifesting, you will flicker in and out of view before fully reappearing. This can deceive Survivors on your next move.
When a Survivor is fully Condemned, Killer Instinct reveals them, and they can be killed.
Survivors can temporarily shut down TVs, preventing you from teleporting and hiding that TV's aura from you.
Sadako can teleport to TVs. Survivors can shut TVs down, but gain Condemned. Too many Condemned means Sadako can kill them.
While Nightfall is active, you are Undetectable and your Teleport ability is faster and recharges more quickly.
You can destroy the lock on a locker with a regular attack.
Using your Teleport power builds the Nightfall meter, but Damaging and Hooking Survivors are the fastest ways to raise it.
There is a screen effect as long as your Remnant is still active. Survivors can disable the Remnant by touching it.
Teleporting to a locked locker, or staying in a locker longer than 8 seconds, will reveal your location to Survivors.
The Dredge's Nightfall power charges more quickly while there are injured survivors in the trial.
The more Survivors Infected with the Uroboros virus, the faster your ability to Bound regenerates.
Maximum Uroboros Infection afflicts Survivors with the Hindered status effect, which slows their movement speed.
The Mastermind launches a Survivor forward if he doesn't collide with anything after grabbing them.
A fully Infected Survivor will automatically be carried if The Mastermind manages to slam them into something.
The Mastermind can slam a Survivor caught in a Virulent Bound into other Survivors.
The Mastermind can Bound twice, causing both injury and Infection. Heal Infection with First Aid Sprays found in Supply Crates.
The Carnifex's speciality is Order, The Assassin's is the Hunt, and The Jailer's is the Patrol.
A Hunted Survivor may return to the Guard's Standard to catch it and end the Hunt.
You cannot create paths over drop down zones, but you can create them through vault locations and pallets.
Guards are assigned in a preset order. Use them judiciously.
When a Guard downs a Survivor, The Knight receives a Killer Instinct notification.
A Guard Hunting a Survivor will only focus on that Survivor. It will ignore others, but will hit them if they enter his path.
The Inspect ability allows you to see where Claw Trapped Survivors are relative to your position.
Survivors may disable deployed Drones. After a while, the Drone will reactivate and return to Stealth Mode
The radars leftmost light indicates a Drone can be deployed. The other signifies a Drone has detected a Survivor.
Survivors that are scanned three times receive a Claw Trap. Additional scans slow them down and reveal them with Killer Instinct.
Deploying a Drone grants the Undetectable status effect for a short duration.
Detection from a Scouting Drone increases your Lock On meter. When full, receive a Claw Trap, which broadcasts your location to the Killer.
Place Biopods strategically around the environment to observe Survivors.
Survivors may disable multiple Biopods at once if they are placed close to each other. Avoid this by spacing them out.
Slipstream Survivors by locking onto them when observing through a Biopod.
Teleport to Slipstreamed Survivors by locking onto them when observing through a Biopod.
Slipstreamed survivors will spread Slipstream to other Survivors who are near them long enough.
Slipstream comes from Biopods or being near other Slipstreamed Survivors. Disable Biopods and remove Slipstream with the EMP.
This icon marks a Survivor that is repairing a Generator, and that Generator's current progress.
This icon marks a Survivor that is currently being chased by the Killer.
This icon marks a Survivor that is healing or mending, or being healed or mended.
This icon marks a Survivor that is recovering and their current progress.
This icon marks a Survivor that is cleansing or blessing a Totem.
This icon marks a Survivor that is interacting with a chest.
This icon marks a Survivor that is interacting with an exit gate switch.
This icon marks a Survivor that is interacting with or is affected by a Killer Power effect.
You can destroy Turrets using your base attack or Tail Attack.
While in the tunnels, you can detect Survivors moving over your location.
Turrets shooting at you will disable your power while in Crawler Mode and increase your cooldown timer when in normal mode.
Select a Control Station before entering or while inside tunnels to highlight the shortest path to reach it.
When destroyed, Turrets take time to respawn at a Control Station.
Deploy Turrets to disable the Xenomorph's power or carry them to avoid being detected while the Killer is in the tunnel.
You are Undetectable for the duration of Hidey-Ho Mode. Your Terror Radius, Red Stain, and Aura are suppressed.
While in Hidey-Ho Mode, you can quickly vault through windows or under pallets using your Scamper ability.
Quickly close in on unsuspecting Survivors with your Slice & Dice ability.
A Slice & Dice can be interrupted by manually activating the attack.
While in Hidey-Ho Mode, Survivors will be disoriented by your Illusory Footfalls; use that confusion to your advantage.
Chucky can quickly become Undetectable, closing in fast with Slice & Dice before unleashing a dangerous attack.
The Unknown is considerably slowed down while charging UVX. Charge your power at the right time!
Use UVX's bounce to surprise Survivors from odd angles during chases.
You have full control of where to spawn Hallucinations. Be creative and try to hide them!
The more Survivors are simultaneously Weakened, the faster you create Hallucinations.
Hallucinations display your Teleport ability's cooldown. Survivors can exploit this information.
The Unknown becomes harder to deal with when it has more Hallucinations available. Be sure to Dispel them!
